Award.AwardTitle: Three Decades of DIMACS: The Journey Continues

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2019, both DIMACS (the Center for Discrete Mathematics and Theoretical Computer Science) and the National Science Foundation's Science and Technology Centers program celebrate thirty years of operation and thirty years of defining and shaping modern research. In today's dynamic research landscape, thirty years is a remarkable milestone, and one that this project proposes to commemorate with a major conference, "Three Decades of DIMACS: The Journey Continues," that looks to the future as it honors the past when DIMACS was one of the original class of NSF Science and Technology Centers (STCs). The conference will explore future directions of traditional DIMACS topics and highlight emerging topics of growing importance. The conference will consider broad questions such as: What is the future of theoretical computer science? What are new challenges for algorithms? For discrete mathematics? How do they tie to applications areas? How do they connect to data science? To AI and machine learning? To privacy and fairness? Finally, the role of centers is changing in a world with instant communication, data everywhere, and disciplines increasingly merged to address fundamental problems of great variety. The conference will explore the implications for DIMACS, STCs, and other centers of various types. The planned program includes many women and underrepresented minorities as speakers and panelists and will highlight innovative programs for broadening participation in computer science and mathematics that may serve as models elsewhere. The program also features discussions of how to educate students to work across disciplinary boundaries and operate in a world where science has become an international activity and the nature of work will change in the age of intelligent machines. It features teachers describing their experiences with innovative education programs and materials that integrate mathematical and computational methods with science content for high school classrooms. Such programs hold promise for building a future workforce that is able to cross disciplinary boundaries and harness the power of computing to address future challenges. Presentations will also address current research that has global societal importance in areas such as sustainability and climate change, epidemiology, homeland security, privacy, and aspects of socially responsible algorithms.

The conference will look to the future with presentations describing ongoing research and emphasizing important challenges and questions that will propel us into the next decade. It will emphasize important themes in computer science theory such as complexity and machine learning (particularly deep learning), as well as the socio-technical challenges, such as privacy and fairness, that arise in a world with increasingly intelligent machines and ubiquitous data. The conference will explore applications in robotics enabled by theory from statistical physics, computational challenges in ecology and related social sciences in the face of climate change, as well as new capabilities in healthcare made possible by advances from computational biology and mathematical epidemiology. Presentations will also look at current and future research directions in traditional DIMACS areas, such as discrete mathematics, optimization, and statistics and their central role in harnessing the data revolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
DIMACS was founded in 1989 as part of the inaugural class of eleven Science & Technology Centers (STCs) selected in a nationwide competition held by the National Science Foundation (NSF). In 2019, both DIMACS and the National Science Foundation's Science and Technology Centers (STC) program celebrated thirty years of operation and thirty years of defining and shaping modern research. We celebrated this milestone with a major conference---Three Decades of DIMACS: The Journey Continues.

With support from this project, the "Three Decades" conference was held on November 21-22, 2019 at the Heldrich Hotel & Conference Center in New Brunswick, NJ. It was organized by Fred Roberts (Emeritus and Interim Director of DIMACS) and Tamra Carpenter (Acting Deputy Director of DIMACS).

With over 130 registered participants, the conference looked to the future as it honored the past. The conference featured a wide range of speakers, at various stages of career, presenting their thoughts on current research and the most pressing challenges of the next decade and beyond. The program included research talks, panel discussions, and reflections by people who engaged with DIMACS in different capacities and at different stages in their careers. Topics included important challenges and questions that will propel us into the next decade in familiar DIMACS themes in CS theory, machine learning, discrete mathematics, statistical physics, optimization, and mathematical and computational biology, as well as in relatively newer topics in sustainability and social responsibility in socio-technical systems. The conference also considered educational challenges in a rapidly changing world, broadening participation in computer science and mathematics, and the future role of centers in a virtually connected world.

The 1987 solicitation by NSF to launch the STC competition challenged investigators to identify complex and important research areas that could benefit from the investment of significant resources to form a center. The centers were to be established at academic institutions, with three primary goals:

1) To perform and promote cutting-edge basic research;
2) To contribute to and improve science and mathematics education; and
3) To work with other institutions, particularly those in industry and government, to enhance the transfer of knowledge.

These goals have remained among the guiding principles of DIMACS and its programs, and they were recurring themes in the conference's presentations and panel discussions.

The conference program included twenty presentations on a wide range of topics and three panel discussions. Presentations were given by:

  • Eric Allender, Distinguished Professor of Computer Science at Rutgers
  • Sanjeev Arora, Charles C. Fitzmorris Professor of Computer Science at Princeton
  • David Banks, Director of the Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI) and Professor of the Practice in Statistical Science at Duke
  • Kostas Bekris, Associate Professor of Computer Science at Rutgers
  • Chang Chan, Associate Professor of Medicine at Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson Medical School
  • Bill Cook, Professor of Applied Mathematics and Statistics at Johns Hopkins
  • Deborah Estrin, Associate Dean and Robert V. Tishman '37 Professor of Computer Science at Cornell Tech
  • Nina Fefferman, Professor of Mathematics & Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at the University of Tennessee
  • Joan Feigenbaum, Grace Murray Hopper Professor of Computer Science at Yale
  • Simon Levin, James S. McDonnell Distinguished University Professor in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Princeton
  • Jaroslav Nesetril, Professor of Mathematics and Director of Institute of Theoretical Computer Science at Charles University
  • Miriam Nuno, Associate Professor in Biostatistics and Surgery Residence at the University of California, Davis
  • Dana Randall, ADVANCE Professor of Computing and co-Executive Director of the Institute for Data Engineering and Science at Georgia Tech
  • Ann Trenk, Lewis Atterbury Stimson Professor in Mathematics at Wellesley College
  • Michael Washington, Health Scientist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
  • Ryan Williams, Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at MIT
  • Peter Winkler, William Morrill Professor of Mathematics and Computer Science at Dartmouth
  • Rebecca Wright, Druckenmiller Professor of Computer Science and Director of the Diana T. and P. Roy Vagelos Computational Science Center at Barnard College
  • Steven Wu, Assistant Professor of Computer Science at the University of Minnesota (now at CMU)
  • Abdul-Aziz Yakubu, Professor of Mathematics at Howard

Adding to the individual research presentations were panels on Education Programs moderated by DIMACS Education Director Midge Cozzens, Security Applications moderated by CCICADA Assistant Director Dennis Egan, and the Future of Centers moderated by Rebecca Wright.

Appearances by NJ Governor Phil Murphy and US Congressman Frank Pallone helped to make the conference memorable.

All of the talks and panels were videotaped and are available online.

We celebrated this milestone with a major conference---Three Decades of DIMACS: The Journey Continues. It was organized by Fred Roberts (Emeritus and Interim Director of DIMACS) and Tamra Carpenter (Acting Deputy Director of DIMACS). With over 130 registered participants, the conference looked to the future as it honored the past. The conference featured a wide range of speakers, at various stages of career, presenting their thoughts on current research and the most pressing challenges of the next decade and beyond. Topics included important challenges and questions that will propel us into the next decade in familiar DIMACS themes in CS theory, machine learning, discrete mathematics, statistical physics, optimization, and mathematical and computational biology, as well as in relatively newer topics in sustainability and social responsibility in socio-technical systems. The conference also considered educational challenges in a rapidly changing world, broadening participation in computer science and mathematics, and the future role of centers in a virtually connected world. The 1987 solicitation by NSF to launch the STC competition challenged investigators to identify complex and important research areas that could benefit from the investment of significant resources to form a center. Roy Vagelos Computational Science Center at Barnard College Steven Wu, Assistant Professor of Computer Science at the University of Minnesota (now at CMU) Abdul-Aziz Yakubu, Professor of Mathematics at Howard Adding to the individual research presentations were panels on Education Programs moderated by DIMACS Education Director Midge Cozzens, Security Applications moderated by CCICADA Assistant Director Dennis Egan, and the Future of Centers moderated by Rebecca Wright. Appearances by NJ Governor Phil Murphy and US Congressman Frank Pallone helped to make the conference memorable. All of the talks and panels were videotaped and are available online.
